issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: This has been seen on several queues showing the allocated MB going significantly above the max MB and it appears to have started with the 2.4 upgrade. It could be a regression bug from 2.0 to 2.4
fields.summary: In Fair Scheduler, reservation fulfillments shouldn't ignore max share

comments.body: After I digging through the code, it seems that in 2.4 resource allocation for reserved containers doesn't check the queue maximum any more. That's why queues are exceeding their maximum when under a certain amount of load

This message is automatically generated.
Hi [~jlowe], We have seen this problem after we upgraded to 2.4. I feel like this is a regression bug. Can you take a look?
Hi [~sandyr], Sangjin told me that you are the best person to review this patch? can you take a look?

Thanks for uncovering this [~l201514].

I think that in this case, in addition to not assigning the container, the application should release the reservation so that other apps can get to the node.
[~sandyr] Thanks for your review. I was think about the same thing.

Thanks [~sandyr] for your feedback. I have updated the patch with a unit test, which will fail without the fix

I just realized an issue with this.  maxResources can be set on parent queues as well, so checking the maxResources of the leaf queue that the app is part of is not enough.  Sorry for not catching this earlier.

A couple more style nitpicks: remember to keep lines close to 80 characters and to put a space after the double slashes that initiate a comment.  Also, FSQueue has a getMaxShare method, so you don't need to go to the trouble of getting the name and passing it to the map in the allocation configuration.

Hi [~sandyr], I was thinking about the same thing regarding to multiple hierarchical queue structure. I have modified the code to handle that case.
This looks almost good to go - the last thing is that we should use Resources.fitsIn instead of Resources.lessThanOrEqual(RESOURCE_CALCULATOR...), as the latter will only consider memory.
